data.title: Always something new to discover or happening
data.text: The Central Library itself is an amazing architectural building to explore.  Check out the catwalk-like view from the  10th floor.  Also, lots of events open to public.  One of largest genealogy resources.  Books, magazines, music, movies you can stream. You can even borrow a hotspot.

data.title: Looks great
data.text: Looks great but inside not so much seems like a good place for a woman to get her butt pinched.A lot of homeless people hang out inside

data.title: Good Books!
data.text: One of the many great libraries at KCLS (King County Library System). I love reading myself and it's a heaven for bookworms!

data.title: Staff great, very efficient
data.text: Needed a place to login--my hotel did not have a business center. They directedme to the floor with hundreds of terminals. Organized, efficient and free.

data.title: Fantastic piece of architecture
data.text: Being a librarian, I like to drag my family to any library we pass during our travels.  I think the Seattle library has been our favorite so far!  This building is amazing!  Our kids loved the escalators and the open atrium.  It is a must see for anyone visiting the city!

data.title: What an architectural marvel
data.text: Just after the building opened (staff was still in the middle of moving and adjusting) we decided to visit, also since it was designed by a fellow Dutchman, Rem Koolhaas. Nicknamed the Cool House, it was all I had read about, from the space, the 'circular' connection between the floors, the layout, structure and general marvel.

data.title: A very interesting Building
data.text: I think this is one of the most exciting buildings in Seattle. It is not the only the outside which was good....how they have used the space on the inside I think was one of the most exciting spaces I have seen for a long time...Forget Pikes Place go here.

data.title: Don't ask why a library - JUST GO!
data.text: Stunning architecturally, and designed with the mind of a librarian -go straight to the 10th floor, enjoy the view, - check out the Seattle room where you can learn the city's history, then walk down the Dewey Decimal path (spiral) to the 6th floor - find the Red (belly) of the the library,or just take the escalator down to the 3rd floor and enjoy a respite a the cafe and pick up a tchotchke in the gift shop - super cool spot for bibliophiles, history buffs, and children.

data.title: A bit Run Down
data.text: When this library first opened, it was flashy, sparkly, and so new.  But over the years, it has not held up well.  Too bad.

data.title: Amazing Views
data.text: I didn't actually visit the library to see any books; I went because the architecture is amazing. The whole building is made from glass. It's definitely worth a stop in if you're in the area.

data.title: This is an awesome must see for tourists!
data.text: You wouldn't expect a library to be on a list of must sees but this one definitely is. The building itself is beautiful and then once inside, you have to go all the way to the top observatory and see the views from there. You can actually look out all of those crazy, contorted windows! The library also had a cool photography exhibition when we were there, which I assume changes out. But all in all, it was worth visiting and taking about an hour or so to look around.

data.title: In awe!
data.text: WOW!  The architecture of this place is absolutely gorgeous.  I was in awe as I went from floor to floor.  The structure viewed from the outside was so unique - I'm a fan of symmetry but man, I could not contain myself!  There's a red hallway which was slightly eery but cool at the same time.  I can't imagine ever leaving if I had access to such an establishment.  The reading areas were spacious and well lit.  And the reflections of the panes were great.

data.title: Space for everyone
data.text: We just visited the library as tourists, and it's a spectacular building to walk around in.  But it's also clear that it's a building for everyone--comfortable spaces for people to work or read.  Throughout the building, the finishes keep changing, so you never feel as though you're in a large faceless institution, but rather in spaces with their own distinct personalities.

data.title: Wasn't needed
data.text: So ugly the old one was gorgeous this place will give you a headache I went into it when it was first built hate it typical Seattle spend unneeded money

data.title: Beautiful Facility
data.text: As a retired librarian, I had to see this library.   The building itself has very interesting architecture and inside it is a state of art facility with an impressive collection.   Helpful staff and wonderful lounge areas if you just want to relax.

data.title: Easily accessible stacks for all
data.text: You get the sense that this library is truly a library for all the citizens of Seattle. The place was teeming with people the evening I visited and not just in the lobby. The stacks were pleasantly full of people browsing the shelves and studying. Very good to see. Not a sight for tourism per se, but very useful if you've got an aching question and just have to get an answer.

data.title: Amazing Children's Library
data.text: I went to explore the children's section and the lovely staff in that area showed me some of their book bag that were made up on specific topics. It was a revelation and I was introduced to lots of new books.

data.title: Bibliophile's dream
data.text: This is the largest library I have ever been in! Interesting architecture allows for both open common areas and intimate study cubes. The spiral staircase and the George Legrady electronic installation were cool! Great place to investigate and take photos. The staff are friendly, knowledgeable and helpful.

data.title: Fantastic Public Library experience
data.text:
Great Public Service to have a facility like this in a major city downtown area.
Always a pleasure to explore!

data.title: Not just a library
data.text: There was so much more than just books categorized by genre. There is a center for job searching, galleries and even art presentations.
